segment.source: Determine which apps are digitally signed on a reference device (Windows 10)
segment.target: Determine which apps are digitally signed on a reference device (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to use AppLocker logs and tools to determine which applications are digitally signed.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to use AppLocker logs and tools to determine which applications are digitally signed.

segment.source: Determine which apps are digitally signed on a reference device
segment.target: Determine which apps are digitally signed on a reference device

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to use AppLocker logs and tools to determine which applications are digitally signed.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to use AppLocker logs and tools to determine which applications are digitally signed.

segment.source: The Windows PowerShell cmdlet Get-AppLockerFileInformation can be used to determine which apps installed on your reference devices are digitally signed.
segment.target: The Windows PowerShell cmdlet Get-AppLockerFileInformation can be used to determine which apps installed on your reference devices are digitally signed.

segment.source: Perform the following steps on each reference computer that you used to define the AppLocker policy.
segment.target: Perform the following steps on each reference computer that you used to define the AppLocker policy.

segment.source: The device does not need to be joined to the domain.
segment.target: The device does not need to be joined to the domain.

segment.source: Membership in the local Administrators group, or equivalent, is the minimum required to complete this procedure.
segment.target: Membership in the local Administrators group, or equivalent, is the minimum required to complete this procedure.

segment.source: To determine which apps are digitally signed on a reference device
segment.target: To determine which apps are digitally signed on a reference device

segment.source: Run Get-AppLockerFileInformation with the appropriate parameters.
segment.target: Run Get-AppLockerFileInformation with the appropriate parameters.

segment.source: The Get-AppLockerFileInformation cmdlet retrieves the AppLocker file information from a list of files or from an event log.
segment.target: The Get-AppLockerFileInformation cmdlet retrieves the AppLocker file information from a list of files or from an event log.

segment.source: File information that is retrieved can include publisher information, file hash information, and file path information.
segment.target: File information that is retrieved can include publisher information, file hash information, and file path information.

segment.source: File information from an event log may not contain all of these fields.
segment.target: File information from an event log may not contain all of these fields.

segment.source: Files that are not signed do not have any publisher information.
segment.target: Files that are not signed do not have any publisher information.

segment.source: Analyze the publisher's name and digital signature status from the output of the command.
segment.target: Analyze the publisher's name and digital signature status from the output of the command.

segment.source: For command parameters, syntax, and examples, see Get-AppLockerFileInformation.
segment.target: For command parameters, syntax, and examples, see Get-AppLockerFileInformation.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Use a reference device to create and maintain AppLocker policies
segment.target: Use a reference device to create and maintain AppLocker policies
